Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2007 03:41AM l82jem wrote: My first FEC tx was Friday - so this is day 6 and the first day I've been able to think straight. I knew with my history of severe morning sickness I was prone to have problems with nausea and that turned out to be true. I tried Marinol on top of the steroid and aloxi but it made me literally feel crazy. So added zofran and phenegran instead. Also took 1/2 an ativan on the really bad days. That worked OK but I've barely been able to eat until today. Probably lost 5 pounds. I can barely remember the last few days I've been so out of it. I'm glad to have a little energy back today, but just checking email has worn me out and I'm ready for a nap!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in JAN 2007 Robbin65 Robbin65

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2007 11:36AM l82jem wrote: Ilene - I've been thinking about your daughter all day. My girls are much younger, but I keep thinking about the teenagers I used to work with. I wonder if part of why she isn't talking to you is out of fear of giving you more to worry about or causing you more stress? Teenagers aren't rational creatures. No matter how hard this is for her now I bet that a few years from she will look back on how much she learned about courage and strength from you during this time. I'm sure even if she's not talking much she is watching you carefully and taking it all in. It must be very scary for a kid that age to have a sick parent. Anyway, I hope she is doing OK. Let us know.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in JAN 2007 Robbin65 Robbin65

After just a couple of minutes in front of the screen I feel terrible. Is it just me?

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2007 09:32AM l82jem wrote: Mizsissy - glad you are back and feeling a little better. Remember that in addition to all of the other side effects chemo does a number on your hormones which really effect your emotional reaction. Sometimes it's just all that chemical craziness going on inside that can make you feel depressed, upset, or like you just can't handle it. Don't let that get you down. I spent hours crying last week for no reason. I swear it was hormones. Chemo has been a lot like pregnancy for me with the nausea, fatigue and crazy mood swings. Hang in there. Oh, and the cat is gorgeous!

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2007 02:14PM l82jem wrote: Dar1 - Hope you are feeling better. I go back on Friday and I will spend each day this week dreading it as it gets closer and closer. Do you know why they had trouble getting the IV started? I have horrible veins and have a little routine that I follow now (at this point I go in telling the nurses how I want it done). Anyway, I drink 1-2 bottles of water before I go in, ask the nurse for 2-3 of those instant warming bags and wrap those all around my hand/wrist for several minutes and then let them start looking for a vein. The combination of being very well hydrated plus having WARM hands seems to make a huge difference.

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2007 04:46AM l82jem wrote: Just curious - are you loosing or gaining weight during chemo? I think the general trend is to gain weight, but I've lost a few pounds with each round and now weigh less than I ever have before. I try to play catch up on the week that I feel good, but at this rate I am going to be way too skinny by the time I finish in May. Normally I'm happy to loose some weight, but I don't want to waste away to nothing.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2007 05:13AM l82jem wrote: Robertin - thank you for mentioning your friend with bc followed by liver cancer. My bc was completely removed with the mastectomy and my nodes were clear so I chose chemo based on my very high oncotype score. I'm always questioning the decision to do chemo as a preventative measure and keep second guessing putting my family through this based on the chance that I might get cancer again. But that story reminds me of exactly why I chose to do this and I do deep down know that it is the right choice. Thanks.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2007 05:06AM l82jem wrote: A couple of days ago I posted about my aunt who had suddenly become ill and was dx with leukemia. We've learned a bit more since then. She is still in the hospital. Her dx is acute leukemia. The doctors gave her a choice. They can help her deal with discomfort and give her blood transfusions and she would have 3-6 months to live. Or, they will give her 10 days of chemo and see if she responds to it. IF she responds to the chemo (and it seems uncertain that she will) she has a 50% chance of going into remission. She decided to try chemo and starts today. They will keep her hospitalized while she is on chemo. We are all a bit shocked by how suddenly this has happened. So - please send some good thoughts that the chemo will help. Thanks.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in JAN 2007 Robbin65 Robbin65

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2007 01:48PM l82jem wrote: Mrs. Shey - finally got a chance to talk to my mom. She said that they don't do rads on the whole body any more. Only for specific areas, with very few exceptions. The most common side effects that she sees are changes to the skin in the areas treated and overall fatigue. For your skin she said that they give a Rx to all of their patients for a skin creme that helps.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2007 04:27AM l82jem wrote: 3 more days until I start chemo. This week has been filled with tests. A CT and bone scan yesterday. A mammo on my remaining side and an echo today. For some reasons the mamo really had me nervous, but they said that everything looked OK. I am going wig shopping tomorrow morning with my husband and have an appointment with my favorite hair dresser Thursday afternoon to get my hair and wig cut. Between all of that and trying to work at least the week is going by quickly. I am incredibly nervous about that first treatment. I seem to have lost my insomnia (after 2 months) only to have it replaced with this feeling of total panic when I wake up in the morning. I think I'll feel better once I pass the point of no return and have the chemo on Friday.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in JAN 2007 Robbin65 Robbin65

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2007 04:31PM l82jem wrote: My appointment was changed again. So I now start chemo tomorrow (Friday). FEC. I had my hair cut short today. I've never had it short before. I probably should have gotten more cut off but I was too chicken to do it. I thought I liked the wig, but even after I had my hairdresser trim it today I don't like the way it looks. Oh, well. I'll figure it out. I can't wait to get my first chemo behind me!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in JAN 2007 Robbin65 Robbin65

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2007 04:11PM l82jem wrote: Day 7 post FEC and starting to feel human again. For some reason the computer gives me a huge headache (which I've been getting a lot anyway). Since I run my own business and do everything on the computer this is causing some real problems. I've only gotten one hour of work done all week which was not what I expected. I admire those of you who are working. I've been so miserable this week that my husband hasn't even made it in to work yet! The nausea stopped a couple of days ago, but I still have terrible stomach aches. It snowed here today bringing everything here in the South to a stop so the girls were home from school and I was awake enough to spend some time with them. That was really nice - we all needed it. They have been very short on mommy time lately. Hoping tomorrow will be better.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2007 06:50AM l82jem wrote: Shrink - by their very nature all of those survival statistics are always out of date. Assume they are higher for people in treatment now vs. 5-10 years ago or more. And, remember that they are just statistics. They don't determine what will happen to you.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2007 06:05PM l82jem wrote: Yes I heard it - the class of chemo drugs that Brian Williams mentioned is (I think) anthracyclines. That includes (if I heard him right) Adriamycin, Eprirubicin, and Doxil. As usual I completely panicked and freaked out. I just finished chemo 3 weeks ago - don't tell me this! Anyway, anyone who's had chemo has likely had two or three different types of drugs, only one of which might fall in this group - so even if it didn't work for us we still had other drugs that do. Karen - you aren't alone in the breaking down in tears dept, but Marsha is totally right.

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 09:21PM l82jem wrote: Ggma - my hair came back all white at first too - really more colorless. The color showed up a few weeks later. So don't worry - you hair might still be blond.
Posts.Title: When does the hair come back??? SisterSuewith2 Ggma

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 08:41PM - edited Oct 5, 2007 08:41PM by l82jem Sunflower - You are NOT a wimp.Â  This stuff is really scarry regardless of your prognosis. Her2 + means that the bc cells in your body are overexpressing a certain receptor. It also means that the drug Herceptin will work to help you. Take a look at this info: www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/...Â  I know several women who have taken Herceptin - most of them have had few or no side effects from it. You can post a question about Her2 in the chemotherapy section of this board - I bet you'll get lots and lots of first hand responses. There are a lot of scary things about chemo. I didn't know how sick I would feel, would I be able to take care of my kids, would I be able to keep working, how would I deal with being bald, etc., etc. Chemo for me was much worse than surgery because I could hide the surgery - but once my hair fell out I looked sick. I couldn't pretend that I was OK. But, with that said - chemo was no where near as horrible as I thought it would be. I got through it, lots of women have, and you can too. It sucks, but you can handle it. The anti-nausea drugs they have now are incredible. I felt crappy during chemo, but I never threw up. Every step of the way so far my anticipation of treatment has always been worse than actually going through it. Hang in there. It will get better. It's OK to be afraid. Â Â

Posts.Content: May 5, 2007 02:02AM l82jem wrote: My OB/Gyn (and many others) recommend getting a baseline mammogram at age 35. Maybe this is a good time to go get a mammo anyway so that you can relieve your worries.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2007 04:57PM l82jem wrote: The wait is by far the worst part. Try to stay busy and keep your mind off of it as much as possible (easier said than done I KNOW). The actual biopsy is not that bad (I had microcalcifications too). It was a little uncomfortable for me and I am a huge wimp when it comes to pain. When you go in ask when you can expect the results. Best of luck - remember that the odds are in your favor that it will turn out to be nothing.

I hope all of you find just as much support and encouragement in this group. Last Janauary I started 6 rounds of FEC after having 2 surgeries. I'm sitting here tonight with hair, eyebrows, a normal energy level and feeling great. Best wishes to all of you!Â
